title: How do we know specific dates in history, when we did not globally accept a date and time until about 1500? How do we know historic dates before 1500 are accurate? - Quora

response.answer_text: Comets! Lunar Eclipses! Etc. One way is to use recorded (and even computed) celestial events to helps us anchor the many different calendars that existed in antiquity. These events are often recorded in antiquity, along with the day (on the calendar) on which they were observed. Because we can often trace these events by day count (google Julian Date), we are often able to anchor the calendar based on the event. As long as the calendar itself was reasonably stable, we can extrapolate forward and backwards based on the anchor points to a precision equal to the stability of the calendar. And actually, the Julian calendar was reasonably stable since it inception in 45 BC, so with a few exceptions, we can anchor those dates via the calendar itself.

We generally interpolate based on the calendars available at the time. We have to know how those other civilizations created and maintained their calendars in order to make historical estimations like that. And through archaeological research we have this kind of information about many ancient calendars. But many others remain to be discovered. A History of Time and Ancient Calendars
